title: Blackletter-esque display type on cookie dough packaging
content:
Spotted this type on a package of gingerbread dough at the supoermarket today. May well be proprietary – it's meant to evoke the kind of folksy blackletter-esque lettering that's found in [traditional rural painting in Sweden](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.nordiskamuseet.se/sites/default/files/styles/adaptive/public/public/amnen/mobler-boende/dalmalning_0198927.jpg?itok=aNthJBGR) (almost rotunda-like, except on the other extreme of Europe) , and I'm not sure whether that's a commercially viable style. But on the off-chance it's available, anyone have any leads?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053im_/http:/typophile.com/files/pepparkaksdeg_3832.jpg)

Font: 

 Custom lettering based on Linotype Dala 

Solved By: 

 [kthomps5](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/typophile.com/user/175823 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [pepparkaksdeg.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/typophile.com/files/pepparkaksdeg.jpg) | 47.79 KB |
author: Birdseeding

comments.content:
Very likely hand-lettered.

A little editing (on the P and p), and Linotype Dala comes close:  
 [http://www.fonts.com/font/linotype/linotype-dala/text](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.fonts.com/font/linotype/linotype-dala/text "http://www.fonts.com/font/linotype/linotype-dala/text")

Edited:  
This round-script Fraktur lettering looks warm and inviting compared to the choppy forms of standard Fraktur.  
Interesting options for uppercase letters include the flowing letterforms of some of the letters in OPTI's Modern Blackletter

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OPTIModernBlackletterAsSTOW_5840.jpg)
  
I suspect that this is one of the relatively few fonts that OPTI independently digitized. OPTI is a defunct operation and its fonts are now orphans. Deiter Steffmann pirated the font and called it Fraktur Moderne.  
Look closely at the lowercase and you will see that behind the flowing curves of the script are the broken stroke letter-forms of the classic Frakturs such as  
Wittenberger Fraktur  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/search/Wittenberger+Fraktur/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/Wittenberger+Fraktur/fonts/ "http://www.myfonts.com/search/Wittenberger+Fraktur/fonts/")  
Neue Luthersche Fraktur  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/neue-luthersche-fraktur/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/neue-luthersche-fraktur/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/neue-luthersche-fraktur/")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/neue-luthersche-fraktur-sb/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/neue-luthersche-fraktur-sb/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/neue-luthersche-fraktur-sb/")  
Walbaum Fraktur  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/search/Walbaum+Fraktur/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/Walbaum+Fraktur/fonts/ "http://www.myfonts.com/search/Walbaum+Fraktur/fonts/")  
Justus Fraktur  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/justus-fraktur/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/justus-fraktur/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/justus-fraktur/")  
Don

Edited:  
Good find Kevin. Linotype Dala does indeed provide a good starting point for the letters.  
Don

Good find on the Linotype Dala – clearly another font with a similar background, inspired by the Dala painting tradition I linked to in the first post. But I do think this _is_ type – because of the similar repeating letters, the layer-based drop shadow and the otherwise completely contemporary packaging:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053im_/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC_0051_4129.jpg)

Note a more conventional fraktur in the "god jul" (Merry christmas) vectory faux-seal. Maybe more products will appear closer to the holiday season?
And thank you Don for placing it in a good historical context! Always can rely on you for that.

I went ahead and emailed Fazer, the manufacturer, and they told me it was custom type by Hans Samuelson of [Samuelstype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317151053/http:/www.samuelstype.com/). I've emailed Hans and asked for more details, let's see what more we can learn. :)

Ah, just got the reply right now from Hans. :) It actually is Bo Berndahls "Dala" as suggested by kthompson5! Heavily customised in Illustrator. I think it's lovely, wish it was an actual typeface. :)
Nice digging! I was hoping too that it would be a typeface, it’s really lovely.
